story:
Amputee Blade Runners set the goal of having at least one runner in each state by the end of 2015! We have launched a West Coast Outreach crowdfunding campaign to raise funds to provide complete running prosthetics to five amputees on the West Coast. We already have identified one recipient, Cindy Petermen Hamlin from Oregon, and plan to have her running by the end of the year. Please support this cause by donating, any amount helps! Check out our website www.amputeebladerunners.com for some stories of the over 35 amputees we have helped become active since 2011. Also, like our fb page so you can stay updated!

Short Summary of Amputee Blade Runners

Amputee Blade Runners (ABR) is a non profit organization based out of Nashville Tennessee that provides amputees with complete running prosthetics free of charge, so these individuals are able to regain active lifestyles.  This is a need of many amputees, because running prosthetics are not covered by insurances.  Our goal is to provide running prosthetics to at least one athlete in all 50 states by the end of 2015. 

Ryan Fann and Aaron Fitzsimmons are both very passionate individuals and chose to combine this passion with their expertise in prosthetics, founding Amputee Blade Runners in 2011. Aaron's desire for helping people began with Camp Easter Seals organization during his undergraduate college experience.  The reward of helping others continued early on in a career as an Occupational Therapist.  He then teamed up with Ronney Snell, and former president of the American Orthotic and Prosthetic Association and served as a prosthetic technician, before going on to become a certified prosthetist.  Ryan Fann is a certified prosthetist (CP) and has a bachelors in Business Administration. Ryan’s journey into prosthetics, however, started when he was three years old and was run over while riding his big wheel in his neighborhood resulting in losing his left leg below the knee. Ryan went on to play as a starting linebacker for his high school.  When playing in a TN all star game, a prosthetic company offered to make him a running leg and Ryan then went on to run track at Tennessee State University (TSU) on a scholarship competing with able bodied athletes, the first to do so in TN. Ryan then ran with the US Paralympic track program earning Gold and Bronze medals in the Athens Paralympic Games.  Together, Ryan Fann and Aaron Fitzsimmons have helped over thirty athletes in eight states get back to running and sports, at collegiate, high-school, and recreational levels, who also serve as ambassadors to other amputee athletes as a part of ABR.

West Coast Outreach Campaign

LA residents Bo Burroughs and Brittany Burke, siblings of Ryan Fann and Brandon Burke, are teaming up to launch the West Coast Outreach of Amputee Blade Runners to help them reach their goal of having an amputee from every state!  On Sunday, November 17th, a red carpet Hollywood event will celebrate this expansion.

In November of 2007, my brother, Brandon Burke, was diagnosed with a rare form of bone cancer, Ewing's Sarcoma.  At the time of discovery, the cancer had progressed to stage three and spread to the bone marrow.  After undergoing an experimental study at the National Institute of Health and nine months of intense chemotherapy, Brandon decided to amputate his leg in July of 2009 due to surgery complications, in order to return to an active lifestyle.  After going off to college and trying to remain active, Brandon was introduced to Ryan Fann who was in the process of starting Amputee Blade Runners. Ryan saw that Brandon was trying to play full-court basketball at his school's rec center, but was unable to properly do so in a walking prosthesis, one that he continually broke. Ryan provided Brandon with his running prosthetic and the expertise needed to make it work, as well as serving as his trainer and mentor.  As an Amputee Blade Runners board member, he now serves as a running coach to above the knee amputees and competes in half-marathons and olympic distance triathlons.

What We Need & What You Get

We are in need of $25,000 funding to reach our goal of providing at least five amputees with stories similar to Ryan and Brandon's with complete running prosthetics.  These resources have the capability to change an individual's life and continue on to help others in need. The unique proposition of Amputee Blade Runners is in the combination of resources, expertise, and passion that allow for us to help amputees get active at the highest of levels at a cost that is as low as possible. Your donation will help change someone's life.

While our goal is to fully fund five individuals, if we do not reach our full $25,000 goal, all proceeds will still benefit as many recipients as possible.  

The Impact

Amputee Blade Runners is a powerful organization which changes people's lives and quality of living.  While health insurance does not cover the costs of running prosthetics and costs are extremely high, ABR makes an active lifestyle a reality.  Based out of Nashville Tennessee, Bo Burroughs and Brittany Burke are determined to spread awareness and support to enable the organization to grow.

Check out our website www.amputeebladerunners.com to see more stories of amputees we've helped get active.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone is in a financial position to donate.  If you are interested in showing your support in other ways, feel free to contact Trey Barclay at ky1500@gmail.com.  Other supportive options include but are not limited to promotion of our donations page and upcoming event, amputee outreach, and volunteer services. If you know any amputees who are looking to get running, or more active, have them check out our website www.amputeebladerunners.com and submit an application!

Don't forget to use your indiegogo share tools and social media platforms to help spread the word!
story_txt:
Amputee Blade Runners set the goal of having at least one runner in each state by the end of 2015! We have launched a West Coast Outreach crowdfunding campaign to raise funds to provide complete running prosthetics to five amputees on the West Coast. We already have identified one recipient, Cindy Petermen Hamlin from Oregon, and plan to have her running by the end of the year. Please support this cause by donating, any amount helps! Check out our website www.amputeebladerunners.com for some stories of the over 35 amputees we have helped become active since 2011. Also, like our fb page so you can stay updated!

Short Summary of Amputee Blade Runners
Amputee Blade Runners (ABR) is a non profit organization based out of Nashville Tennessee that provides amputees with complete running prosthetics free of charge, so these individuals are able to regain active lifestyles.  This is a need of many amputees, because running prosthetics are not covered by insurances.  Our goal is to provide running prosthetics to at least one athlete in all 50 states by the end of 2015. 
Ryan Fann and Aaron Fitzsimmons are both very passionate individuals and chose to combine this passion with their expertise in prosthetics, founding Amputee Blade Runners in 2011. Aaron's desire for helping people began with Camp Easter Seals organization during his undergraduate college experience.  The reward of helping others continued early on in a career as an Occupational Therapist.  He then teamed up with Ronney Snell, and former president of the American Orthotic and Prosthetic Association and served as a prosthetic technician, before going on to become a certified prosthetist.  Ryan Fann is a certified prosthetist (CP) and has a bachelors in Business Administration. Ryan’s journey into prosthetics, however, started when he was three years old and was run over while riding his big wheel in his neighborhood resulting in losing his left leg below the knee. Ryan went on to play as a starting linebacker for his high school.  When playing in a TN all star game, a prosthetic company offered to make him a running leg and Ryan then went on to run track at Tennessee State University (TSU) on a scholarship competing with able bodied athletes, the first to do so in TN. Ryan then ran with the US Paralympic track program earning Gold and Bronze medals in the Athens Paralympic Games.  Together, Ryan Fann and Aaron Fitzsimmons have helped over thirty athletes in eight states get back to running and sports, at collegiate, high-school, and recreational levels, who also serve as ambassadors to other amputee athletes as a part of ABR.

West Coast Outreach Campaign
LA residents Bo Burroughs and Brittany Burke, siblings of Ryan Fann and Brandon Burke, are teaming up to launch the West Coast Outreach of Amputee Blade Runners to help them reach their goal of having an amputee from every state!  On Sunday, November 17th, a red carpet Hollywood event will celebrate this expansion.

In November of 2007, my brother, Brandon Burke, was diagnosed with a rare form of bone cancer, Ewing's Sarcoma.  At the time of discovery, the cancer had progressed to stage three and spread to the bone marrow.  After undergoing an experimental study at the National Institute of Health and nine months of intense chemotherapy, Brandon decided to amputate his leg in July of 2009 due to surgery complications, in order to return to an active lifestyle.  After going off to college and trying to remain active, Brandon was introduced to Ryan Fann who was in the process of starting Amputee Blade Runners. Ryan saw that Brandon was trying to play full-court basketball at his school's rec center, but was unable to properly do so in a walking prosthesis, one that he continually broke. Ryan provided Brandon with his running prosthetic and the expertise needed to make it work, as well as serving as his trainer and mentor.  As an Amputee Blade Runners board member, he now serves as a running coach to above the knee amputees and competes in half-marathons and olympic distance triathlons.

What We Need & What You Get

We are in need of $25,000 funding to reach our goal of providing at least five amputees with stories similar to Ryan and Brandon's with complete running prosthetics.  These resources have the capability to change an individual's life and continue on to help others in need. The unique proposition of Amputee Blade Runners is in the combination of resources, expertise, and passion that allow for us to help amputees get active at the highest of levels at a cost that is as low as possible. Your donation will help change someone's life.
While our goal is to fully fund five individuals, if we do not reach our full $25,000 goal, all proceeds will still benefit as many recipients as possible.  





The Impact
Amputee Blade Runners is a powerful organization which changes people's lives and quality of living.  While health insurance does not cover the costs of running prosthetics and costs are extremely high, ABR makes an active lifestyle a reality.  Based out of Nashville Tennessee, Bo Burroughs and Brittany Burke are determined to spread awareness and support to enable the organization to grow.
Check out our website www.amputeebladerunners.com to see more stories of amputees we've helped get active.


Other Ways You Can Help
Not everyone is in a financial position to donate.  If you are interested in showing your support in other ways, feel free to contact Trey Barclay at ky1500@gmail.com.  Other supportive options include but are not limited to promotion of our donations page and upcoming event, amputee outreach, and volunteer services. If you know any amputees who are looking to get running, or more active, have them check out our website www.amputeebladerunners.com and submit an application!
Don't forget to use your indiegogo share tools and social media platforms to help spread the word!

story:
Be Part of the CHANGE!

HELP Dr. Jones WIN the SUPREME COURT APPEAL case!

 

Note:  Dr. Jones has announced that he has received enough donations and pledges to continue to practice!!  Good News!!

THANK YOU TO EVERYONE WHO DONATED AND HELPED SPREAD THE WORD!

 

But, Please Keep Donating!  He's not in the clear yet.

We hope to reach our goal of $20,000!

 

He still NEEDS FUNDS to support his upcoming fight to

WIN the Supreme Court Appeals case.

 

Why is the Appeal so important?

Dr. Jones:

"A victory will be extremely important not only for me, but also for other LLMD’s, because it would establish a highly significant precedent, requiring a higher burden of proof in order to prosecute physicians who are brought before their medical boards.  In my case, it also could positively affect the outcome of the remaining set of charges that were brought against me."

"I must admit that the legal proceedings, stretching as they have over the past 7 years, have taken a huge toll on my office."

"Your repeated words of encouragement and reassurance have convinced me to persist – along with my grave concern that, should the CMEB prevail, conditions for other LLMD’s could become ever more difficult."

 

PLEASE SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN !!!!

And Follow it on Facebook, LIKE US at

http://www.facebook.com/childrenslymenetwork

 

(Children's Lyme Disease Network is working with Dr. Jones on this online fundraiser. The Network is NOT taking any portion of the donations.)

==========

A Call for Help  -  Dr. Jones:

"We were managing to break even financially until Hurricane Sandy hit, followed by a significant snowstorm.  Patients, unable to leave their homes, had to cancel their appointments, and we saw almost no one during a two-week period.  The loss of revenue, approximately $36,000, was devastating, and the office has been unable to recover financially.... 

In a nutshell, I am experiencing a financial crisis, and I will be forced to close my practice unless I am able to raise $40,000 within the next few days."

==========

Who is Dr. Jones?

 He is a pioneer in the diagnosis and treatment of Lyme Disease. He has treated more children with Lyme Disease than any other doctor in the world. He is revered by parents and a hero to countless children, many gravely ill suffering from late stage Lyme Disease. For their families, Dr. Jones has been their last hope.

Over the past 40 years, Dr. Jones has treated more than 15,000 children and adolescents, from countries where many thought Lyme did not exist, including China, Australia, even Saudia Arabia.

At age 82, Dr. Jones is relentless in his quest to get these children well. He works 6 days a week. And sleeps only 4 or 5 hours a night. During his "free" time, Dr. Jones reviews stacks of notes and charts on "his kids" (patients). He says, he has no time to rest, there are simply too many sick kids coming through his door. (He is one of only a handful of pediatricians in the U.S. trained, specifically, in treating Lyme Disease.)

Yet, he is a humble physician, living modestly. It's not about the money, or the prestige or having material things, he says. It's about getting these children to smile again. 

"When they walk through my doors, most look very sick. You can see it their face. They don't smile, they have dark circles under their eyes. This is not just a job for me," he says. "It's more of a calling."

 

Watch how Dr. Jones helped 5 year old Colin:

http://youtu.be/ZFFnLjSBBU4

Watch a teenagers struggle with Lyme Disease:

http://youtu.be/mpB287Yx9iQ

 

A Brief History -

Dr. Jones is one of the "founding" physicians heavily involved in treating the disease when it was "discovered" in Connecticut in the 1960's. 

Despite extreme pressure from outside medical entities, including supporters of IDSA (Infectious Disease Society of America), Dr. Jones has held true to his convictions, determined to properly diagnose and treat children with Lyme Disease. 

Before anyone heard of Lyme Disease, Dr. Jones had begun treating a growing number of children suffering with disabling arthritic pain. They were being diagnosed with Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis (JRA). But, almost by accident, Dr. Jones discovered that by treating these patients with high doses of antibiotics, their arthritis would disappear. When he stopped antibiotics (prematurely), the symptoms would return. He decided if the patient fit the "clinical diagnosis" of Lyme Disease, he would  continue antibiotics until ALL symptoms COMPLETELY resolved, regardless of how long it took.  It worked, children got better. Today, he continues this "unconventional" treatment plan. (His opponents believe in treating with antibiotics for only a brief, few weeks, even if symptoms are still present.)

Brief summary - Dr. Jones' court hearings - Under Our Skin:

http://www.underourskin.com/news/feeling-pressure-update-dr-charles-ray-jones

View a video excerpt - Lyme Doctors under attack: (Under our Skin)

http://youtu.be/X_jwFVkXWtc

 

Children's Lyme Disease Network

The Children's Lyme Disease Network is a newly formed organization, developed under the guidance of Dr. Jones.  Together, we are launching this online fundraiser.

 

For more information:

lymedisease.org

ilads.org

Brief summary - Dr. Jones' court hearings - Under Our Skin:

story:
The History of My Idea

I worked for a company that was trying to use magnets to target drugs for cancer.  We made tiny particles that could absorb cancer drugs and were also metallic.  You could put the particles into someone’s blood vessels, then hold them in a cancer tumor using a giant magnet.  This allowed the drug to sit in the tumor and not circulate around the patients’ body.  It was a good idea; Chemotherapy drugs are very toxic and it would be nice if they could just stay in a tumor and not kill healthy tissues. There are some publications listed below that describe the detailed science of the process.

The idea seemed to work well and carried through a clinical trial.  It was even orphaned by the FDA, meaning, they would allow for a faster review process because the idea was so promising.  

The company expanded a bit and held a bigger clinical trial, and the particles stopped working.  The company folded.  It was thought that there was something going-on between the particles and the cancer drug that was unpredictable chemically.

I moved-on to other projects and mostly forgot about the particles.  Later, I became a mother and taught science at a small school.

Thirteen years after the company folded, I was sitting in my school laboratory watching a physics student of mine play with a magnet and some iron filings.  I suddenly completely understood what had happened to make the original clinical trial work, and the latter trial fail; it was a “Eureka” moment.

Days later I was at a friend's house, visiting, while our kids played and she showed me Amanda Palmer's TED Talk.  I was inspired.  I realized I needed to get this information out of my head and into the world. I was the only one who knew it. If I'm right, this could have a huge effect on future cancer treatment therapies.

 

Inspriation attribution

Amanda Palmer's TED Talk:

http://www.ted.com/talks/amanda_palmer_the_art_of_asking.html

 

Amanda Palmer's Kickstarter Campaign:

http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/amandapalmer/amanda-palmer-the-new-record-art-book-and-tour

 

My Idea

If you play with a magnet and some iron filings in a see-through container, you will notice that the iron aggregates into sharp little pointy spears as you move the magnet close.  When you move the magnet away gently, the spears fall back apart into particles.  Imagine that the iron particles are inside a blood vessel, inside a tumor, aggregating and falling apart.  My idea is that this physical action tears-up the blood vessel, and destroys the tumor.

The evidence for this is that during the original clinical trial with the particles (see history, above), the magnet was held over the patient for a long period of time.  No one knew how long would be necessary, so we had the patient stay under the magnet for an hour or more.

Then, some laboratory research made us believe that only a few minutes of “magnet time” was required for the particles to work their way into the tumor and stay there.  So, for the trial that did not work, the magnet was only applied for ten minutes.

If the aggregate spears were destroying the tumors, these results make sense.  It also makes sense that in the successful trial, tumors that were removed from patients after treatment appeared “torn up” inside.  In the successful trial (in some cases), patients with tumors that were too large to remove shrank and were removed surgically, saving the patients’ lives.

(An unedited animation of the science portion of the video is posted under the "Updates" tab)

What the Money is For

The money for this campaign will go for an initial laboratory investigation of my idea.  My hope is that the science will be strong enough to publish the results, and perhaps to interest additional scientists and investigators.  I need a minimum level of funding to initiate pre-clinical trials of the concept at two certified labs.  I will also need to purchase a rare earth magnet with the strength of the one used in the old clinical trials, uniform sized iron particles, and a few other small items and chemicals.  The testing will be in vitro (taking place in a test tube, culture dish, or elsewhere outside a living organism) which means, of course, no living organism will be used or harmed.

Why do we only need $11k? Isn't medical research astronomically expensive?

 
This is just the first step, the proof of concept if you will.  If the initial testing proves correct, we'll move on to toxicology testing, assay developement, tox batch production, and so on and and that's where costs go up.  This project gets the ball rolling. Anyone who signs up now will continue to be in the loop on the news of further testing, patent progress, future research funding and investment updates.

Why You Should Help

If I am correct, this technology could potentially help anyone with a solid tumor cancer (that is nearly all cancers except leukemia and lymphoma).

 

What You Get


We've listed some incentives on the side. Mostly we're trying to make this fun for people who aren't "Sciency" but when it comes down to it, everyone has been touched by cancer. We'll get stickers, t-shirts, if we go over our goal we'll come up with some more stretch-goal, fun, goodies.  But mostly this is to help move us toward a possible, better, treatment of cancer.

 

FAQ 

People have sent in great private questions!  I'm going to answer them in public.
 
Do you have access to a lab facility?
I have three possible labs for in-vitro and organ modeling of the idea; I will get results from two. These are experienced contract pre-clinical labs where I (or friends) have done work.  In-vitro and preclinical results would allow me to take it back to physicians who used the 2001 system that has some similarities.
 
What is your background and relevant experience?
My background is in Biology, Tox, and most heavily in Project Management for big pharma. I’ve taken several drugs from idea through Phase III.  My most relevant experience for this idea is from design and validation of preclinical testing and assays of a similar product.
 
Although I have a $150,000 certification in making drug products commercial, my best experience for this was having my hands in the lab at the very beginning of an idea (see publications).
 
I would (obviously) not act as the PI; I have dual PIs in Tox and Physics interested, and a doctor in mind. 
 
Do you have a patent?
I filed a patent the night I had the idea; it does not infringe on earlier patents as my mechanism is completely different from the earlier proposal.  The budget allows for completion of the patent process.
 
Why use crowd funding?
The normal financial process at this stage is to seek investors who would like to profit from the drug.  The other normal thing is to keep it a complete secret until you have something wonderful to tell the press.
 
The problem is this.  Once you bring-in someone trying to profit from the drug, you are on a timeline of financial milestones that lead to an IPO or commercialization.  Science does not often fit that timeline.  This idea is a classic example. 
 
When we initially tested the carrier product in the lab, the results did not support the mechanism that was proposed.  Even at that early stage, people were fired for suggesting we take some more time and investigate.  After the original successful clinical trial, no one was interested in anything but sticking-to the financial timeline of the project.  So, the second trial failed, as do many trials.  I believe this paradigm is holding back technology in medicine.
 
That is why I’m making an effort to keep this grassroots, transparent, and non-profit.  I have determined that cancer, and other diseases, are simply too important to entrust to the current system.  I hope we can set a precedent for funding the actual scientific process.
 

Reference Articles


Journal of Controlled Release

Volume 74, Issues 1–3, 6 July 2001, Pages 335–340

Proceeding of the International Symposium on Tumor Targeted Delivery Systems

Adsorption and desorption of chemotherapeutic drugs from a magnetically targeted carrier (MTC)

S. Rudge , C. Peterson, C. Vessely, J. Koda, S. Stevens, L. Catterall




Biomaterials 21 (2000) 1411}1420

Preparation, characterization, and performance of magnetic

iron}carbon composite microparticles for chemotherapy

S.R. Rudge,*, T.L. Kurtz, C.R. Vessely, L.G. Catterall, D.L. Williamson"

!FeRx Incorporated, 18200 W. Hwy 72, Arvada, CO 80007, USA

"Department of Physics, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO 80401, USA

Received 22 July 1999; accepted 4 October 1999

 

Music attribution:

  • "Slime Patrol" by voyageurs (http://voyageurs.bandcamp.com)
  • "Warp" by voyageurs (http://voyageurs.bandcamp.com)
  • “The Future Soon” by Jonathan Coulton (http://www.jonathancoulton.com/)
  • “Lost” by Amanda Palmer and the Grand Theft Orchestra (http://amandapalmer.net/)

 

Cancer ribbon color choices:

We'll get stickers, t-shirts, if we go over our goal we'll come up with some more stretch-goal, fun, goodies.  But mostly this is to help move us toward a possible, better, treatment of cancer.
 


FAQ 
People have sent in great private questions!  I'm going to answer them in public.
 

Do you have access to a lab facility?I have three possible labs for in-vitro and organ modeling of the idea; I will get results from two. These are experienced contract pre-clinical labs where I (or friends) have done work.  In-vitro and preclinical results would allow me to take it back to physicians who used the 2001 system that has some similarities.
 

What is your background and relevant experience?My background is in Biology, Tox, and most heavily in Project Management for big pharma. I’ve taken several drugs from idea through Phase III.  My most relevant experience for this idea is from design and validation of preclinical testing and assays of a similar product.
 
Although I have a $150,000 certification in making drug products commercial, my best experience for this was having my hands in the lab at the very beginning of an idea (see publications).
 
I would (obviously) not act as the PI; I have dual PIs in Tox and Physics interested, and a doctor in mind. 
 

Do you have a patent?I filed a patent the night I had the idea; it does not infringe on earlier patents as my mechanism is completely different from the earlier proposal.  The budget allows for completion of the patent process.
 

Why use crowd funding?The normal financial process at this stage is to seek investors who would like to profit from the drug.  The other normal thing is to keep it a complete secret until you have something wonderful to tell the press.
 
The problem is this.  Once you bring-in someone trying to profit from the drug, you are on a timeline of financial milestones that lead to an IPO or commercialization.  Science does not often fit that timeline.  This idea is a classic example. 
 
When we initially tested the carrier product in the lab, the results did not support the mechanism that was proposed.  Even at that early stage, people were fired for suggesting we take some more time and investigate.  After the original successful clinical trial, no one was interested in anything but sticking-to the financial timeline of the project.  So, the second trial failed, as do many trials.  I believe this paradigm is holding back technology in medicine.
 
That is why I’m making an effort to keep this grassroots, transparent, and non-profit.  I have determined that cancer, and other diseases, are simply too important to entrust to the current system.  I hope we can set a precedent for funding the actual scientific process.
 
Reference Articles

Journal of Controlled Release
Volume 74, Issues 1–3, 6 July 2001, Pages 335–340
Proceeding of the International Symposium on Tumor Targeted Delivery Systems
Adsorption and desorption of chemotherapeutic drugs from a magnetically targeted carrier (MTC)
S. Rudge , C. Peterson, C. Vessely, J. Koda, S. Stevens, L. Catterall

Biomaterials 21 (2000) 1411}1420
Preparation, characterization, and performance of magnetic
iron}carbon composite microparticles for chemotherapy
S.R. Rudge,*, T.L. Kurtz, C.R. Vessely, L.G. Catterall, D.L. Williamson"
!FeRx Incorporated, 18200 W. Hwy 72, Arvada, CO 80007, USA
"Department of Physics, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO 80401, USA
Received 22 July 1999; accepted 4 October 1999

"Warp" by voyageurs (http://voyageurs.bandcamp.com)

“The Future Soon” by Jonathan Coulton (http://www.jonathancoulton.com/)

“Lost” by Amanda Palmer and the Grand Theft Orchestra (http://amandapalmer.net/)

story:
לעברית יש ללחוץ כאן

Short Summary

Did you know that Alzheimer's disease is not even recognised as a disease by the Ministry of Health in Israel?

This situation has gone on for way too long!

It needs to be changed!

The announcement of a general election in 3 months time offers us a golden opportunity to raise awareness to a level that will make this cause impossible to ignore.

Please help

What We Need & What You Get

The more funds we can bring in, the more awareness we can raise. 

We have the plans ready for an aggressive and effective PR and lobby campaign.

The more you give, the more will change, and the faster it will happen.

The Impact

We have defined 7 points for change:

  1. To have Alzheimer's disease recognised in law as a disease such as any other from the moment of diagnosis (currently treatment is only provided for end-stage sufferers who are in need of hospitalisation)
  2. An official recognition of Alzheimer's as the looming health crisis it is (such as has already been done in the UK, US and elsewhere)
  3. The creation of a national plan for the fight against Alzheimer's
  4. For the test to diagnose Alzheimer's to be included in the national health insurance service package
  5. For day care for Alheimer's sufferers to be budgeted by the government
  6. For home therapy for Alzheimer's sufferers to be budgeted by the national health insurance
  7. For a national awareness and educational program to be launched to educate the public about Alzheimer's disease

Sounds reasonable, no?

By the way, all donations are eligible for a charitable receipt, according to Article 46 of the Israeli tax code 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • You can share your Facebook header to raise awareness of our campaign (Facebook.com/Melabev)
  • You can join us for our annual 2-day hike in the Negev desert on November 27-29
  • If you can't come for the walk, sponsor a walker! Walk4Alz.com

And that’s all there is to it.

 

הכריז ראש הממשלה (ושר הבריאות)  על בחירות בתוך 3 חודשים.

ניתנה לנו הזדמנות של פעם בכמה שנים להעלות את נושא מחלת האלצהיימר, ואת מלחמתם של החולים במחלה והתומכים בהם, על סדר היום.
 
אנו, עמותת מלב"ב, יוצאים כבר היום בקמפיין על מנת להפוך את המאבק במחלת האלצהיימר, והטיפול בחולים בה, לנושא לגביו נוכל לגייס תמיכה רחבה בקרב מבקשי תמיכתנו לבחירתם. נגייס את תמיכתם היום כשהם צריכים אותנו - ולאחר הבחירות נזכיר להם את הבטחותיהם למען אלו שנשכחו בגלל ששכחו.
 
הכל טוב ויפה, נכון? כן... רק שאנחנו חייבים גם לממן כזה קמפיין
 
נשמח אם לדעתך הדרך הטוב ביותר לעזור הינה לתמוך כלכלית - יש להרגיש חופשי להכניס לקופת הקמפיין כל סכום שברצונך לתת, וגם ושתף את המעשה ואת הקמפיין עם אחרים!
 

(דרך אגב - כל תרומה תזכה את התורם לקבלת מס המוכרת לפי סעיף 46 לפקודת המס) 

בנוסף, במהלך שלושת החודשים עד ליום הבחירות נבקש את עזרתך בשיתוף ובהפצה של מסרים, תמונות ומכתבים שישמשו לקידום מטרות הקמפיין שלנו. נשמח מאוד ונודה לך על כל שיתוף פעולה שביכולתך לתת. הדרך היחידה בה נוכל לגרום לשיפור אמיתי באיכות החיים של אלו בהם אנחנו תומכים היא על ידי השתתפותך, יחד עם השתתפותם של כל חברי עמותת מלב"ב.
 
להלן הנקודות העיקריות אותן נקדם:
  1. הכרה ע"י משרד הבריאות במחלת האלצהיימר כמחלה לכל דבר ועניין מרגע אבחונה (כיום מוכר רק מעת אישפוז סיעודי בשלבים הסופניים של המחלה)
  2. הכרה ממשלתית במגיפת האלצהיימר (כנעשה בארה"ב, באנגליה, ובמדינות מערביות נוספות)
  3. הכנת תוכנית לאומית למאבק במחלת האלצהיימר
  4. מימון ממשלתי לבדיקת האבחון למחלת האלצהיימר במרפאות זיכרון מקצועיות
  5. תקצוב ראוי לטיפול בחולי מחלת האלצהיימר במרכזי יום
  6. הכרה בסל התרופות לפעילויות תראפויטיות במסגרת ביתית לחולי מחלת האלצהיימר
  7. תוכנית ממשלתית להגברת המודעות הציבורית למחלת האלצהיימר
 
זכרו,גם אתם עלולים לשכוח!

story:
This is a story about Hope.

{Who}: Mitchell Lyne.

{What}: He has battled renal failure since the age of eight.

{How}: By the grace of God and spirit of humanity, he has received THREE kidney transplants by the age of 19.

{When}: The latest surgery was in August 2012.

{Where}: Believe it or not, his kidney donor was found through Facebook; this unexpected gift alone seemed like a social media miracle, and that's why I'm hoping you can facilitate another miracle in the New Year. Things seemed to be going great for several months post-op, then suddenly his blood work showed signed of distress. This beautiful "recycled" organ is rejecting because his confused body thinks it's a foreign object, but this foreign object is meant to save his precious life. A treatment that could turn things around and save the kidney, Velcade, was not covered by his insurance company. It costs upward of $100K and we're on a mission to raise the money.

 

You see, this young man is the definition of resiliency and strength. He *never* complains, continues to smile in the face of adversity, and just wants to live another day. Most kids his age are lucky enough to be in college sitting in class; he is sitting in the hospital all day long, several days a week. Hope lives and love wins.

story:
It's tax time once again....

You have just made your annual visit to Uncle Sam, and now you find yourself asking the question,  "What to do with that pesky refund check?"

Let's face it, many of you will just end up blowing most of it on cheap wine or beer or just foolishly gamble it all away.  Why do that again this year when you can truly do something remarkable with it, something that will really make a difference in thousands of people's lives?  

Donating just a small portion of your tax refund to this cause will help fund much needed research and clinical trials of hundreds of talented researchers around the globe, who are trying to find a treatment or cure for the eye disease known as Choroideremia.

 

So what is Choroideremia and why should I donate to this cause?

Choroideremia is a genetic eye disease that is slowly stealing away the sight of those who suffer from it, like myself and thousands of other men (and some women) in the US and thousands more around the world.

People who suffer from Choroideremia (or CHM for short) are missing a gene that produces something called REP-1 protein.  This protein supplies nourishment for the photo-receptor cells of the choroid layer of the retina.  Without if, those cells slowly die off.  The eyesight and peripheral vision of the person with CHM slowly deteriorates until complete blindness is the final result.

It does not have to be that way if you help.  There are many exciting avenues of research being explored right now for this disease.  Phase one clinical trials are already underway in the UK and some are planned for the very near future in the US.  All that is missing is funding.  

 

Our group, the Choroideremia Research Foundation, has vowed to raise around $3 million dollars in the next few years, and every single dollar counts.  

If you donate to this campaign, every single one of those dollars will go the CRF, and the money they get goes right to the research teams they are funding, including Dr. Jean Bennett at the University of Pennsylvania and Dr. Miguel Seabra and his team in the UK and others.  This campaign is just a small way to contribute to this amount.

You get the satisfaction that you are helping save our sight and help in the fight against blindness in general around the world.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you didn't get a tax refund this year, or things are too tough for you in this economy to donate right now to any cause.  

In that case, you can still be of huge importance to us.  Please copy the link to this campaign and put it on your Facebook timeline, your Twitter feed, and all other social media you subscribe to.

The more that word gets out about our cause, the more people have the ability to help.

story:
Hi, 

We are a small group of parents. Our children have been diagnosed with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD), a life threatening genetic disorder which we are trying to fight against. We are starting this fund raising campaign for our Parent Project Muscular Dystrophy (PPMD) which is now very close to finding a cure to this disorder through Stem Cell therapy.

Your donations will help us tremendously and take us closer to realizing this dream. The outcome will help the lives of not only our children but of many more across the globe in years to come!

DMD was discovered in the late 1800’s.  DMD is an X-linked recessive form of muscular dystrophy. Patients become increasingly disabled as they get older, muscle degeneration, difficulty walking, breathing, and premature death. 

The disorder is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene, located in humans on the X chromosome (Xp21). 

International statistics today show that this disorder affects 1 in every 3600.
(for more information please see gallery) 

We believe we have found a cure. 

With your help this dream can be realized.

In 2012, being optimistic about the research happening across the globe in different phases, we parents teamed up with TranScell Biologics (GMP Certified) of Hyderabad, India and initiated the in-vitro research in their laboratory to better explore, understand and assess the possibility of a cure.

We, PPMD-Mumbai, managed to fund this pre-clinical activity entirely ourselves by each member of the organisation personally contributing in every way possible.

The study which was initiated in 2012 ended in 2013 with very promising results!

Post this we have re-analysed and verified the results through several laboratory tests under the guidance of leading Neurologists in this field.

Today, being further motivated by confirmation of these positive results we are moving closer to the potential cure.

Earlier this year we have conducted another round of tests and gathered the approvals required. We are now commencing with the clinical trials and rehabilitation of patients. 

This is where we need your help

We have raised some money to cover certain costs.

However, we are still short by at least 25000$ to run the clinical trials efficiently and the rehabilitation programmes needed for kids who will undergo this therapy and are affected with DMD.

So please donate now. We need more than our goal of 25000$ to continue our efforts to aid DMD patients in every way possible.

Your money will:

1)  Cover the non-medical costs involved in running the clinical trials 

·  transportation of patients, which can be a daunting task given their disability, 

·  take proper care of patients during the trials by providing the additional assistance and emergency services that might be needed

2)  Rehabilitation activities of the Patients

·  Physio therapy sessions

·  Recreational activities (tours, social website for patients)

·  Counselling for kids from early age

3)  Awareness program to inform other parents, patients and doctors of the research done and the results achieved. One of the top priorities of this would be to educate patients and the general public about the true effects and correct methodologies concerned with stem cell therapy and muscular dystrophy.

Our sole primary objective is to work collectively towards providing information on treatments for children irrespective of what caste, creed and different levels of society or state they belong to.

Other ways you can help:

  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools on this page to Like, tweet, G+, or email our campaign to your friends. This will raise our Gogo Factor and could give us a spot on the front page!
  • Talk about the Cure for Muscular Dystrophy crowdfunding campaign in your blog or Facebook page.
  • Tell all your friends about us!

You can find out more about DMD and our organisation on www.mdsociety.org  

Our Medical Team

Earlier this year we have conducted another round of tests and gathered the approvals required. We are now
commencing with the clinical trials and rehabilitation of patients. This is where we need your help
We have raised some money to cover certain costs. 
However, we are still short by at least
25000$ to run the clinical trials efficiently and the rehabilitation programmes needed for kids who will undergo this therapy and are affected with DMD.
So please donate now. We need more than our
goal of 25000$ to continue our efforts to aid DMD patients in every way possible.Your money will:
1)  Cover the non-medical costs involved in
running the clinical trials 
· 
transportation of
patients, which can be a daunting task given their disability,  
· 
take proper care
of patients during the trials by providing the additional assistance and
emergency services that might be needed
2)  Rehabilitation activities of the Patients
· 
Physio therapy
sessions
· 
Recreational
activities (tours, social website for patients)
· 
Counselling for
kids from early age
3)  Awareness program to inform other parents,
patients and doctors of the research done and the results achieved. One of the
top priorities of this would be to educate patients and the general public
about the true effects and correct methodologies concerned with stem cell therapy and
muscular dystrophy.Our sole primary objective is to work collectively towards providing information on treatments for children irrespective of what caste, creed and different levels of society or state they belong to.Other ways you can help:
Please use the Indiegogo share tools on this page to Like, tweet, G+, or email our campaign to your friends. This will raise our Gogo Factor and could give us a spot on the front page!
Talk about the Cure for Muscular Dystrophy crowdfunding campaign in your blog or Facebook page.
Tell all your friends about us!
You can find out more about DMD and our organisation on www.mdsociety.org  Our Medical Team

story:
DECEMBER 25 2013      WHAT A CHRISTMAS PRESENT

JEFF CLARK MAVERICKS SURF SHOP ENDORSES GOODLIFEMOBILITY

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FG2m_Gk-4Q4    poster size: 24x36 with trimming to fit frame  (see in perks, personally autographed for you)

The Mission

Hi, My Name is Dainuri Rott.  I am a Surfer, Veteran and Founder / Executive Director of GoodLife Mobility (GLM).

GLM is a 501(c)(3) non profit dedicated to innovative engineering . We provide the world with our adaptive water sports technology.

Our mission is to improve the quality of life for people facing physical and emotional challenges by developing innovative mobility solutions for flat water and ocean recreation.

GLM's present focus is providing  individuals with limitations with electric powered Adaptive SUPs (Stand Up Paddle Boards) and electric powered Adaptive Wave Skis for surfing.

Our Ambassadors 

In the flat water world of lakes, rivers, and estuaries, our ambassador is Veteran Sean Ryan.  In the video above you heard Sean talk about his experience with our innovative adaptive SUP in a San Francisco Bay Marina. 

In the surfing world our ambassador is Veteran Mark Thornton, a wave-skier with paraplegia (pictured below.)   Mark lives in the San Diego area and is excited about sharing the joy of the Adaptive Wave Ski with fellow veterans.

With Sean leading the way, our goal is to build a robust and reliable adapted SUP, for use by Veteran's Program Outreach and various Challenged Athletes in the San Francisco Bay Area. We'll be working with the recreation therapists at the Palo Alto and Menlo Park Veterans Hospitals  and with established Veterans organizations such as Paralyzed Veterans of America (PVA) and Disabled American Veterans (DAV). Also we'll be doing our own outreach to get veterans and athletes with challenges out on flat water of the bay for fun, mobility and independence. 

We will also do the same with ambassador Mark Thornton and the wave ski board in the San Diego area.

Where will your contribution go?

We are a lean organization fueled by volunteer labor and a minimum of cash.  In our  project to build an electric assist surfboard for an injured competitive surfer (see story below) we had 6 volunteers donating over 1700 hours, and 5 business sponsors who donated materials and labor. 

We plan to run the Water Mobility outreach program in  a similar fashion and will continue to use volunteers to cover outreach for the SF bay area and San Diego.

The following chart shows how your contributions will be spent  for the adaptive SUP and the adaptive Wave Ski campaign. Raising $30,000.00

 Our Story

How did GoodLife Mobility's mission evolve?  Our roots are in surfing, and in 2003, I built my first prototype.  As an aging surfer, I was running out of paddle power and was tired of missing literally hundreds of waves.

A pivotal moment for my work came in 2004 when I met a courageous young surfer who became a quadriplegic after being injured by a fluke wave.  With no feeling from the chest down and very limited use of his arms, he did not let his condition stop him. I watched in awe as his surfing friends pushed him into scary waves in Ventura, California.

I immediately knew that others needed electric assist technology more than I did. That realization, plus years of engineering innovations, resulted in  the world’s first joystick-controlled, steerable electric surfboard. Using this board  at a Malibu beach test session in June 2012, the  young surfer was able to surf independently again. He caught a lot of waves, hung out in the surf for over an hour, and even used the electric assist board to tow his buddies!

Below are pictures of Julia Olson (who sustained a spinal cord injury in a car accident) getting ready and riding the joystick controlled board in Foster City Ca.  She had a blast and would love to have access to one. (Please note we are not building a Joy Stick controlled board as part of this campaign.)

             

Most of the effort put into the electric surfboard was self-funded and assisted by small donations. In 2010, we got a big boost from a quality of life grant from the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation; most of the engineering effort is from volunteers, individuals, and companies who have generously donated their time and resources.

To view a listing of some of the contributors and see the board in action, please click the link below:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bbq1Uz5nR3w

Where we are now

Over the years, I’ve encountered a lot of other people who, like the courageous young surfer, could benefit from this adaptive technology.   This is especially true of our warriors who were wounded in service to our country.

I believe in the healing power or fun, recreation, and just being out on the water.  My sense is that experience helps heal all of us, especially if we're dealing with gnarly conditions like PTSD.

I am especially eager to give back the joy of being on the water to our returning vets.  I'd like to see every VA Hospital and recreation center have adaptive water sports and this Indiegogo campaign is an important beginning toward that goal.

Our ongoing supporters

We have been overwhelmed by the support provided by so many folks along the way. 

Here's a picture of me with Jerry Lopez, my long time surfing and SUP hero, about to sign a SUP poster, one of the Perks available for your contribution to the campaign. Jerry has supported us along with two more of my heroes, Maverick's big wave surfers Jeff Clark and Frosty Hesson.   (Jeff donated his shaping expertise and Frosty has contributed signed copies of his memoir, another Perk you can receive.)

       

What you can do to contribute

Sure, we'd love for you to find a great perk or simply make a donation to our campaign. We'd love you for you to share in this adventure and get as many smiles on as many Challenged Athletes and Veteran faces as possible.

And remember, your contributions are tax-deductible (minus the retail value of your perk.) 

If you are not in a position to donate please spread the word by e-mailing your friends, through your social media network - Facebook, Twitter, etc. and of course word of mouth.

View the perks here (and click on the picture for a larger view):

https://www.dropbox.com/sh/8bia1kri5wkrz01/q0LVIiZGgS

In Closing:

The young men who serve in foreign wars are at the top of my heroes list.  Please help GoodLife Mobility support them in their journeys back to civilian life.  Let's make it fun and joyful. 

Cowabunga, 

Dainuri Rott

story:
Who We Are

Swastha, which is Nepalese for health, is our main focus. We are an organization of students attending the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia. Annually, we raise money to travel to Nepal. While we are there, we fund a medical clinic to serve the area outside of Kathmandu while concurrently conducting research into health problems in the community. We hope the data we collect during this trip will provide us with a good guide for planning our future trips and indicate where to direct our relief efforts.

What We Ask For 

While we continue our funding efforts year round, we are trying something new.  Your donations will help us get on a plane this winter and contribute to:

  • Transportation efforts for a group of 10-12 students and our advisor to travel to Nepal 
  • Minor medical supplies utilized at the camps 
  • Educational packets/activities for Nepalese citizens to emphasize the importance of preventative medicine and healthy living habits

The Impact

Our group has attempted to gain a deeper understanding of the country, and the pattern that we have observed is that limited access to health care acts as a significant contributor to the health problem. Illnesses that could be easily treated instead escalate to acute and/or fatal diseases in Nepal merely because of the lack of treatment. 

We seek to distinguish this service trip from an average “run-of-the-mill” student trip by engaging in a two-pronged methodology: assisting in delivering health care with a trained medical team and carrying out research for the ultimate goal of a sustainable health system. In thinking of a sustainable approach, we hope to promote programs that are “owned” and operated by the local community. In support of this founding philosophy, we partner with The Mountain Fund to set up a health clinic with local doctors. 

Research Initiative for Winter 2014-2015:

We would like to understand how Western medicine is interpreted and its relationship with the urban and rural healthcare systems currently in place.  Though we will be looking at the all members of the community, this year's data initiative, in a broad scale, is mainly focused on assessing and promoting progress in the MDG area of Maternal & Neonatal Health in 3 Categories:
1: Health Information Awareness
2: Assessment of the help needed for gender-specific diseases and ailments
3: Social Circles and Healthcare Access
 
We want to take a look at health from a social standpoint. Information on how circles of women's social interactions impact access to healthcare would be gathered, using GIS mapping and an interview-like model similar to that which was used to collect the previous data during the health camp. 

Demographic information will be collected along with a Health Assessment profile: Basic physical, with exiting need types and classification (inferctious/noninfectious, communicable/noncommunicable) and treatment given.
Part of our interest in visiting a school or two is to assess the awareness and practice of healthy behaviors and habits in young children.  Ideally, this would be done through a series of activities and fun cultural exchange.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word for Swastha Nepal:

  • Spread the word on your favorite social media site about the campaign 
  • Visit our blog spot at http://swasthan.blogspot.com to experience out past trips and take a glimpse at the Nepal that you can help

story:
My name is Charlie Penrose. In December 2013 I was diagnosed with testicular cancer - although I am still undergoing treatment the testicle was removed and the cancer was cured. All my initial treatment took place at King’s College Hospital and for their work I am immensely grateful - they reacted with immense speed in both the diagnostic and operative stages and I have them to thank for my recovery and fitness.

To celebrate still being alive, and to show in some small part my immense gratitude to King’s for their work, I am undertaking a series of challenges over the course of 2014 culminating in an Ironman Triathlon at the end of the year. At present these challenges include plans for climbing the 3 Peaks, walking from London to Cornwall, riding fixed gear from London to Paris and kayaking the English Channel.

I am seeking funding for my year of challenges - I do not expect others to cover all of it and the £1500 target would only cover a portion of my costs. I need a triathlon specific bike, wetsuit, entry fees, travel costs, promo clothing etc. I would be immensely grateful for any contribution.

story:
We are a registered 501(c)(3) with twenty years of experience in global health. We enable sustainable change by bringing medical supplies, equipment and experts to places that need them. We rely on donations from people who share our belief that everyone everywhere has a right to modern medicine.  100% of donations go to our programs!


What We Need 


For over ten years, Global Healing has operated a volunteer pediatric clinic in the one public hospital in Roatán, Honduras. Our clinic has performed over 30,000 patient exams. We have become well-integrated into the Roatán health care system, and have built strong relationships with local medical, public health, political and business leaders, as well as with the families we serve. We are actively pursuing efforts in perinatal medicine, newborn care, inpatient pediatrics, and, most recently, expanded emergency and trauma services.

Unfortunately, however, the pediatric clinic is severely under-equipped, and is often without even the most basic medicines for pregnant women, infants and children, including:

  • infant acetominophen (Tylenol) 
  • children's ibuprofen (Advil) and diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
  • urinalysis tests
  • albendazole (de-worming treatment)
  • albuterol (asthma treatment)  
  • iron supplements; glycerine suppositories; diaper rash ointment
  • prenatal vitamins, pregnancy tests

What Your Help Can Do

No medical clinic should be unable to bring a child's fever down because of lack of resources. We work hard to secure an adequate supply of donated volunteer hours, prescription medications, supplies and biomedical equipment. But we need your help providing these absolutely essential basics to keep our clinic safe and its patients healthy! 100% of your donation will go directly to this cause.

Volunteer surgeons perform operations at the clinic--most on children under 5.

    Other Ways You Can Help 

    Even if you can't help by making a contribution today, we still want your support! Help us get the word out by sharing this campaign on social media or telling your friends about it. And follow us on Facebook or Twitter to learn more about the development of our projects in  Roatán and at other program sites. 

    Want to learn more about  Roatán? 

    The Bay Islands have a total population of approximately 60,000 from African, Caribbean and Latino/Mestizo backgrounds. Roatán is the largest of the Bay Islands and is home to the only public hospital. The neighboring islands of Utila and Guanaja have only public health clinics. Approximately half of the population lives in poverty, and there are substantial economic, educational and health disparities, which contribute to the need for health promotion and health care services. Since 2003, together with our local partners, Global Healing has made a significant impact in the care of the pediatric population, but there is a lot of work left to do. 

     Roatán is also a renowned destination for divers and snorkelers. Its warm climate, beautiful beaches and diverse coral formations and marine life make it an inviting vacation spot.

story:
Hrvatska verzija nalazi se ispod. Croatian version below.

We have reached our initial $3.000 goal and already installed Sewantess in Milana's home. 

Our stretch goal is to reach $6.000 for the deployment of one more Serwantess for Kristijan who suffers from ALS (read more below).



Serwantess Helps Disabled

E-Glas is a high-tech social venture from University of Rijeka, Croatia. It was born through our volunteer work with persons with disabilities.

In order to help disabled persons we have produced Serwantess. 

Serwantess is an electronic voice-controlled assistant for persons with disabilities. Having Serwantess, one can literally talk with his home and thus control lights, TV, telephone, door opening, radio, media player, air conditioning, or even surf the web.

We have built the first voice controlled system five years ago. Since then, Serwantess has become a reliable product which serves persons with severe disabilities to have a better and a more independent life. We have already made over 30 installations of Serwantess systems in the users' homes in different parts of Croatia.


Award-Winning Social Enterprise

Our project has been presented at various events worldwide, and received acknowledgment of various organizations:

  • Best presentation award at Balkan Venture Forum, Belgrade 2012
  • Winner at PYMWYMIC Impact Days, Amsterdam, April 2013
  • Selected pitch for CEE Impact Day, Vienna, June 2013
  • Grant obtained by Croatian Ministry of Entrepreneurship and Crafts, August 2013
  • Scholarship recipients for SOCAP13, San Francisco, September 2013
  • Invited to pitch at the EVPA Annual Conference in Geneva in November 2013
  • Invited to pitch at the Doing Good and Doing Well conference at IESE Business School in Barcelona, February 2014


Life Changing Donations

In Croatia, assistive technology such as Serwantess is not subsidized by the government. Also, persons with disabilities are often in a very poor financial situation. We need your help to provide Serwantess systems to disabled persons for free.

For each 3.000 $ raised one highly disabled person will get a donation of a complete Serwantess system with the following functions:

  • voice control for TV
  • voice controlled light
  • voice controlled door unlocking with video sureveillance of the front door
  • web browser control via voice commands
  • making and receiveing phone calls by voice commands

We will also provide the installation and the two-year guarantee for the whole Serwantess system.

The users are chosen based on the level of disability and poor financial conditions. You can be sure that your donations will have a great impact on their lives.

We will produce a video report talking about the impact that you created. It will be a personalized thank you message from our team and persons with disabilities.

Our mission is all about helping people, so thank you for being our partner in making disabled persons more independent and making their lives better!


The Impact

Persons that cannot control their body are completely dependent on other people’s help. Without the possibility to use their hands they need help from their family members and other caregivers with all tasks of everyday life. Also, they are typically forced to pay for additional help of personal assistants.

The life quality of a disabled person is severely affected, as well as of the whole family of a disabled person. A disabled person feels constant frustration not being able to do anything on her own, and at the same time their loved ones are under constant pressure, needing to be around all the time. Additionally, a disabled person is completely deprived from privacy, cannot even have a private telephone conversation since there should be a person nearby to facilitate a phone call for her. As a consequence, everyone is unhappy, both a disabled person and the family, which is completely exhausted both emotionally and financially.

With Serwantess, a person with disability regains the independence. The simple tasks of everyday life become feasible and can be done without the need to ask others for help. It is also a big help for the whole family since they don’t have to be at constant service day and night. Furthermore, Serwantess reduces the need for paid personal assistants.


Kristijan and Milana Need Our Help

Milana is 34 years old and she lives in Rijeka. She suffers from multiple sclerosis which forced her to use a wheelchair and made it almost impossible to use her hands normally. Milana graduated sociology at the University of Zagreb but due to progressive disease she is not able to work and to live independently. We already managed to reach our first $3.000 milestone for this campaign and to help Milana get her Serwantess system and become more independent. Milana's Serwantess is currently being prepared and she will get it very soon.



Kristijan is 19 years old and he lives in Zagreb. He was a healthy young person until his 18th birthday when he was diagnosed with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS is a progressive neurological disease which made him severely disabled, making it impossible for him to use his hands. Kristijan lives with his mother which takes care of him. Our next milestone is to help Kristijan become more independent with the help of Serwantess voice control.


The Team

We formed a highly educated team of experts in the fields of information and communication technologies, digital signal processing, speech recognition and synthesis, acoustics, electronics and automation. Our wish is to use our expertise and knowledge to help all people living in difficult circumstances due to physical disability, old age, illness or disability in general.


We Care

When starting the campaign, Miroslav, the founder of E-Glas, decided to personally promote the campaign by riding in the wheelchair on the streets of Croatia. To someone it might look as a joke but for us it is a very serious task of raising the awareness of the Serwantess project and to make people more ready to help persons with severe disabilities and with no income to become more independent.


User Stories

Marko Arambašić

Marko Arambašić is a doctoral student at the University of Zagreb. Marko suffers from muscular distrophy which tied him to the electric wheelchair. Serwantess helps him to live more independently.


Antonio Cvetojević

Antonio is 19 years old. He lives in Zagreb and suffers from cerebral palsy. Several months ago, Antonio got his Serwantess system which made him more independent in performing everyday tasks.


Mario Kutle

Several years ago I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. Until then, I lived normally and enjoyed life like every other person. The disease affected my hands which I could not use because they went paralyzed. It spread to my legs too. Since then, everything is much more difficult because I can only move in wheelchair. Disease made impossible for me to go out and live independently like every other healthy person. 

However, thanks to Serwantess, everyday life has become much easier. Serwantess is a great help for me. Thanks to Serwantess, I don't lie in dark all the time because on my command System turns the light on. Furthermore, when someone is at the front door I can see that person on my television and I can tell Serwantess to unlock the door. With Serwantess, I can control my television and make a phone call. All I need to do is say the name of the person I want to call.

Altogether, my life is much better since I have Serwantess. Although I live with my parents, I am independent. If there wasn't for Serwantess, I would need help 24/7, I would always have to bother someone for simple everyday activities. This way I can do it myself.

Other Ways You Can Help

The financial contribution is not the only way you can help. If you would like to support us you can also:

  • Tell you friend about this campaign via e-mail, Facebook or Twitter.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!


 Hrvatska verzija. Croatian version.

Servus pomaže osobama s invaliditetom

E-Glas je visokotehnološka tvrtka sa Sveučilišta u Rijeci koja je nastala kroz volonterski rad s osobama s invaliditetom. Kako bi pomogli osobama s invaliditetom razvili smo Servus.

Servus je elektronički sustav koji osobama s invaliditetom omogućava da pomoću glasovnih naredbi upravljaju svojim domom. Sa Servusom doslovno možete razgovarati i na taj način kontrolirati svjetlo, TV, telefon, radio, klima uređaj, otvoriti vrata, pa čak i surfati internetom.

Prvi Servus sustav napravili smo prije pet godina. Od tada je Servus postao pouzdani proizvod koji služi osobama s teškim invaliditetima kako bi imali bolji i vodili samostalniji život. U Hrvatskoj smo do sada instalirali preko trideset Servusa u domovima osoba s različitim vrstama invaliditeta.

Donacije koje mijenjaju život

Asistivna tehnologija kao što je Servus u Hrvatskoj nije sufinancirana od države. Budući da se osobe s invaliditetom često često nalaze u vrlo teškoj financijskoj situaciji, trebamo Vašu pomoć kako bismo omogućili da osobe s invaliditetom dobiju Servus sustav potpuno besplatno.

Za svakih 3,000 dolara koje prikupimo, jedna osoba s teškim invaliditetom će dobiti donaciju koja sadrži kompletni Servus sustav sa sljedećim funkcijama:

  • glasovno upravljanje TV-om
  • glasovno upravljanje svjetlom
  • mogućnost otvaranja vrata glasom te video nadzor ulaznih vrata
  • kontrola web preglednika glasovnim naredbama 
  • samostalno telefoniranje i primanje poziva glasovnim naredbama

Korisnici se biraju prema stupnju invaliditeta i financijskih (ne)mogućnosti. Možete biti sigurni kako će Vaše donacije uvelike utjecati na njihov život.

Po uspješnom završetku kampanje snimit ćemo i video o svakoj pojedinoj osobi koja je dobile Servus zahvaljujući Vašim donacijama. To će biti osobna poruka zahvale našeg tima i osobe s invaliditetom koja je dobila Servus sustav.

Cijela naša misija svodi se na pomaganje ljudima. Stoga Vam puno hvala što ste naš partner u poboljšavanju života osobama s invaliditetom.

Servus vraća samostalnost

Osobe koje nemaju kontrolu nad svojim tijelom u potpunosti su ovisne o pomoći drugih. Bez mogućnosti da koriste svoje ruke, trebaju pomoć članova obitelji i drugih njegovatelja za najobičnije svakodnevne radnje. Također su često prisiljeni plaćati dodatnu pomoć.

Kako i osobama s invaliditetom, tako i obiteljima tih osoba, kvaliteta života im je često loša. Osoba s invaliditetom neprestano je frustrirana što ne može ništa samostalno raditi te su i njihovi bližnji pod stalnim pritiskom time što moraju biti uvijek u mogućnosti priskočiti u pomoć. Nadalje, osoba s invaliditetom nema privatnosti i ne može obaviti ni telefonski razgovor a da nije pokraj nje ili njega osoba koja pomaže oko samog telefonsa. Zbog toga su svi nesretni i to je vrlo iscrpljujuće – emotivno i financijski.

Sa Servusom osoba s invaliditetom ponovo zadobiva svoju neovisnost. Jednostavni zadatci svakodnevnice postaju lako ostvarivi i mogu biti obavljeni bez pomoći drugih osoba. Kako uz pomoć Servusa obitelj ne mora biti cijelo vrijeme uz osobu s invaliditetom, time je i Servus od velike pomoći cijeloj obitelji. Ne moramo ni spominjati kako Servus umanjuje potrebu za plaćanjem dodatnih pomoćnika.

Kristijan i Milana trebaju našu pomoć

Milana ima 34 godine i živi u Rijeci. Ima multiplu sklerozu koja ju je prisilila na korištenje invalidskih kolica i onemogućila da normalno koristi ruke. Milana je diplomirala sociologiju na Sveučilištu u Zagrebu, ali zbog progresivne bolesti ne može raditi niti samostalno živjeti. Zahvaljujući prvim donatorima, Milana je već u polovici ove kampanje dobila svoj Servus sustav kako bi mogla samostalnije živjeti.

Kristijan ima 19 godina i živi u Zagrebu. Do nedavno je bio potpuno zdrav dok mu nije za 18. rođendan dijagnosticirana amiotrofična lateralna skleroza (ALS). ALS je progresivna neurološka bolest koja mu je pored ostaloga onemogućila da normalno koristi ruke. Naš sljedeći cilj je pomoći Kristijanu kako bi postao neovisniji uz pomoć Servus sustava.

Naš tim

Naš tim sastoji se od visokoobrazovanih stručnjaka u području informatičke i komunikacijske tehnologije, digitalne obrade signala, raspoznavanja govora i sinteze, akustike, elektronike i automatike. Svojom sposobnosću i znanjem želimo pomoći svim osobama koje žive u teškim okolnostima zbog njihovog tjelesnog invaliditeta, bolesti i dr.


Priče korisnika

Mario Kutle (38) iz Zagreba

Prije nekoliko godina sam obolio od multiple skleroze. Do tada sam normalno funkcionirao, volio kretati se i uživati u životu kao i ostali zdravi ljudi. Bolest je došla naglo, prvo mi je udarila na oči zbog čega sam privremeno izgubio vid, a onda prešla na ruke, kojima se nisam neko vrijeme mogao služiti, a sada i na noge. Sve je puno teže od tada, pa se mogu kretati jedino uz pomoć invalidskih kolica. Bolest mi je onemogućila da živim slobodno i neovisno kao što svaka zdrava osoba. No zahvaljujući Servusu moj svakodnevni život je puno lakši. Servus mi je od velike pomoći. 

Ne moram stalno ležati u krevetu u mraku, jer na moju naredbu upali svjetlo. Zatim, kada mi netko pozvoni na ulazu u stan, tu osobu vidim na kameri i kažem Servusu da mi otvori vrata. Sa Servusom mogu upravljati televizorom i nazvati nekoga na telefon. Telefon koristim tako da Servusu kažem ime osobe koju želim nazvati.

Sve u svemu, živim puno bolje, jer sam neovisan unatoč tomu što živim s roditeljima. Da nema Servusa, uvijek bi mi netko trebao pomagati, nekoga bih morao gnjaviti, a ovako sam mogu obavljati neke radnje.

Hrvatska verzija nalazi se ispod. Croatian version below.We have reached our initial $3.000 goal and already installed Sewantess in Milana's home. Our stretch goal is to reach $6.000 for the deployment of one more Serwantess for Kristijan who suffers from ALS (read more below).Serwantess Helps DisabledE-Glas is a high-tech social venture from University of Rijeka, Croatia. It was born through our volunteer work with persons with disabilities.In order to help disabled persons we have produced Serwantess. Serwantess is an electronic voice-controlled assistant for persons with disabilities. Having Serwantess, one can literally talk with his home and thus control lights, TV, telephone, door opening, radio, media player, air conditioning, or even surf the web.We have built the first voice controlled system five years ago. Since then, Serwantess has become a reliable product which serves persons with severe disabilities to have a better and a more independent life. We have already made over 30 installations of Serwantess systems in the users' homes in different parts of Croatia.Award-Winning Social EnterpriseOur project has been presented at various events worldwide, and received acknowledgment of various organizations:
Best presentation award at Balkan Venture Forum, Belgrade 2012
Winner at PYMWYMIC Impact Days, Amsterdam, April 2013
Selected pitch for CEE Impact Day, Vienna, June 2013
Grant obtained by Croatian Ministry of Entrepreneurship and Crafts, August 2013
Scholarship recipients for SOCAP13, San Francisco, September 2013
Invited to pitch at the EVPA Annual Conference in Geneva in November 2013
Invited to pitch at the Doing Good and Doing Well conference at IESE Business School in Barcelona, February 2014
Life Changing DonationsIn Croatia, assistive technology such as Serwantess is not subsidized by the government. Also, persons with disabilities are often in a very poor financial situation. We need your help to provide Serwantess systems to disabled persons for free.For each 3.000 $ raised one highly disabled person will get a donation of a complete Serwantess system with the following functions:
voice control for TV
voice controlled light
voice controlled door unlocking with video sureveillance of the front door
web browser control via voice commands
making and receiveing phone calls by voice commands
We will also provide the installation and the two-year guarantee for the whole Serwantess system.The users are chosen based on the level of disability and poor financial conditions. You can be sure that your donations will have a great impact on their lives.We will produce a video report talking about the impact that you created. It will be a personalized thank you message from our team and persons with disabilities.Our mission is all about helping people, so thank you for being our partner in making disabled persons more independent and making their lives better!The ImpactPersons that cannot control their body are completely
dependent on other people’s help. Without the possibility to use their hands
they need help from their family members and other caregivers with all tasks of
everyday life. Also, they are typically forced to pay for additional help of
personal assistants. 
The life quality of a disabled person is severely
affected, as well as of the whole family of a disabled person. A disabled
person feels constant frustration not being able to do anything on her own, and
at the same time their loved ones are under constant pressure, needing to be
around all the time. Additionally, a disabled person is completely deprived
from privacy, cannot even have a private telephone conversation since there
should be a person nearby to facilitate a phone call for her. As a consequence,
everyone is unhappy, both a disabled person and the family, which is completely
exhausted both emotionally and financially.

With Serwantess, a
person with disability regains the independence. The simple tasks of everyday
life become feasible and can be done without the need to ask others for help.
It is also a big help for the whole family since they don’t have to be at
constant service day and night. Furthermore, Serwantess reduces the need for
paid personal assistants.Kristijan and Milana Need Our HelpMilana is 34 years old and she lives in Rijeka. She suffers from multiple sclerosis which forced her to use a wheelchair and made it almost impossible to use her hands normally. Milana graduated sociology at the University of Zagreb but due to progressive disease she is not able to work and to live independently. We already managed to reach our first $3.000 milestone for this campaign and to help Milana get her Serwantess system and become more independent.
